content.description: The Y Crack is an obvious Y-shaped crack left of the hiking trail to the top.  The climb is straightforward and follows two variations - each of the same grade - to the top.  The climbing is pretty much in the first half of this climb, so easy is the final terrain.
content.location: The Y Crack area is about 80 feet left of the hiking trail to the top.  The Y Crack formation is obvious and not at all a crumbly crack.

content.description: Start below the incipient crack system 7 feet left of Benjamin Bunny.  Stay within a foot of the crack, passing two horizontal cracks to steeper terrain up high.
content.protection: no fixed gear.  Limited placement opportunities.
content.location: Start 7 feet right of Benjamin Bunny (about 30 feet left of the Y Crack)

content.description: Wolf Tracks makes use of the finger ledges up the blank face between Step In Wolf and the Arachnophobe's Nightmare crack.  The holds are not obvious from the ground, and foot placement on the start is tricky.
content.protection: no fixed gear.  No pro placement possible.
content.location: Use The Y Crack as a guide - 12 feet to the left, just left of Step In Wolf but before the big, obvious spider crack.

content.description: Step In Wolf is the obvious finger crack 7 feet right of The Y Crack.  Climb straight up 18 feet to a horizontal crack, then finish up and right, following the seam over chipped-ledge foot placement and through horizontal cracks.
content.protection: no fixed gear.  Small Tricams, cams, and nuts.
content.location: Located a few feet right of The Y Crack and just left of a huge chunk of lighter rock in the lowest face, Step In Wolf is the smallish next crack in the wall.  This is just left of the hiking trail to the top of the outcrop.

content.description: Begin a few feet to the right of The Y Crack.  Follow the splash of quartz up the face directly between The Y Crack and Step In Wolf.  Stay off the cracks.
content.protection: no fixed gear.  Small gear if anything at all.
content.location: Start just between the Y Crack and the next obvious crack to the right.  The route is on an obvious seam of quartz.

content.description:
This is the easy terrain just left of Ghostwalker to the blocky terrain of the Wolf's Head Pillar.  Numerous paths to the top abound.  The whole section features easy terrain, big ledges for feet, cracks, and generally overmany options for hands and fingers. 

  This is a quicker climb to the top than traversing around the side to the footpath, but be cautious in foregoing the rope: some areas of the base have large rocks and stumps enough to make a fall unpleasant at least.
content.protection: no fixed protection.  The cracked and jumbled terrain features opportunities for pro, but the brevity of the routes makes this largely unnecessary.

climbs.name: Just Another Hold on the Wall

content.description: This route climbs the face directly between the two leftmost quartz cracks (Ghostwalker and A Round Peg in a Square Hole).  Begin under the shallow lightning-bolt-shaped scar.  Climb up and past the shallow, right-facing corner/flake to the blocky terrain above.  Finish on good holds.
content.location: Located dead center between two prominant quartz veins in the leftmost section of The Main Wall.  A shallow, slightly-discolored scar in the rock about ten feet off the ground marks the route.

content.description: The face between Wolfman Jack (5.6) and Hungry Like a Wolf (5.5) yields tricky, small holds with a crux about 15 ft up.  The blocky finish up right is easy after the face.  Do not use either crack system to the right or left.
content.protection: no fixed gear.  Little opportunity for placement aside from a couple of horizontal seams in the first 20 feet.
content.location: Start 7 feet left of Benjamin Bunny (25 feet left of The Y Crack) and finish over same ground as Benjamin Bunny.  Stay on the face - do not use eight crack.

content.description:
Ghostwalker works up the leftmost quartz vein of The Main Wall, about 30 feet right (south) of the Wolf's Head Pillar.  This is a great route for beginners and for practice placing protection. 

  Use the numerous hand- and footholds to ascend the slabby terrain.  Stay within six inches of the quartz.  The upper portion is steeper but features great holds.  The crack contains many opportunities for gear placement, but a TR can be set up without ascent.
content.protection: no fixed gear.  Takes all ranges of pro; bring an assortment of small nuts and medium-to-large cams.
content.location: The vein is the obvious left-most quartz streak up The Main Wall, about 30 feet to the right of the Wolf's Head Pillar.

content.description: First Hard On ascends the face directly right of the Ghostwalker crack.  The easy crux is right on the start, and the rest of the climb features easy terrain for beginners.
content.location: Start five feet right of Ghostwalker.  Climb the face, staying right of the obvious quartz crack.

content.description:
Cate's Crawl is a the easiest crack climb in this section of The Main Wall.  Move up big ledges and blocky terrain to the top. 

  Look for the large 'notch' in the top of the wall - Cate's Crawl finishes through that feature.

Benjamin Bunny (5.1) is a left-leaning crack about 20 feet left of The Y Crack.  Very good route to practice pro placement. 

  Follow crack up and to the left to a ledge.  Finish on blocky wall, just left of the broken edge.
content.protection: no fixed gear.  Small-to-medium nuts and cams.
content.location: Find the left-leaning crack left of The Y Crack.  The start is under a blocky outcrop at the top.

content.description: Arachnophobe's Nightmare is the larger crack to the right of The Y Crack.  During the warmer months, this crack seems to fill up with spiders, particularly daddy longlegs.  If you're not a fan of spiders, use the face instead.
content.location: Arachnophobe's Nightmare is located ten feet right of The Y Crack, and just to the left of a small copse of young trees next to the cliff.

climbs.name: A Round Peg in a Square Hole

content.description: "A Round Peg in a Square Hole" follows the obvious but not-as-brash slash of quartz on The Main Wall, ten feet to the right of Ghostwalker.  Follow the slightly-leaning system of cracks and holds through parallel cracks near the top.  Stay right with the crack - it is slightly harder terrain than to the left.
content.location: "Round Peg..." starts about ten feet right of the bright quartz crack of Ghostwalker, a smaller but noticeable twin slash of white up the dark rock.

content.description:
The Main Wall is a highly concentrated area of easy climbs coupled with easy access to the top, ideal for beginners but with some variety for seasoned climbers and those looking practice rappel or trad technique. 

  The Main Wall is located on the West Face of Wolf Rock, directly off the main trail.  It stretches south from the Wolf’s Head Pillar (located on the NE corner of Wolf Rock) to the ramp of a top access trail.  The Main Wall features a variety generally easy climbs up blocky, cracked black rock streaked with white marble.  Many of the climbs are 20 feet or less and are hardly more than 5th class scrambles, but a few sections are taller and with interesting features.  The routes are slabby and are fun routes for beginner climbers, although numerous crack systems provide numerous gear placement opportunities.
